III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of youth
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On an unknown date, when youth previously resided at the facility,
they were sexually assaulted by someone named Person A,
unknown if the person was another youth or an adult. It was also
alleged that staff call youth inappropriate names.
Investigation Interviews:
On 08/05/2024 an email was sent to the Foster Care Worker
advising of investigation and request a response or call with any
additional information or questions.
On 08/05/2024 an email was received from Chief Administrator.
She advised myself and DHHS Specialist that the agency does
not have any staff named Person A. She did confirm that Youth B
has a similar name and was placed at the agency from 03/07/24 -
03/27/24.
On 08/07/2024 an on-site visit was made to the facility. An
interview was held with the Chief Administrator. She was advised
of the allegations. She denied any knowledge of any
inappropriate physical or sexual contact between Youth A and
Youth B. On 10/03/2024 an in-person interview was completed
with Chief Administrator. She denied knowledge of staff speaking
to youth in a negative or derogatory manner or making any threats
toward youth. She reported that she is confident that the youth
would report any such concerns directly to her or another
supervisor. She specifically denied any knowledge or reports of
Lead Supervisor calling a youth stupid and retarded or stating that
his “momma should have swallowed him”. Chief Administrator
also denied knowledge of Staff 1 making statements to Youth A or
any other youth about “laying him out”.
2

On 08/07/2024 a voicemail message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call with any additional information.
On 08/15/2024 Youth A was interviewed via telephone. The
DHHS specialist was present in person with the youth. Youth A
reported he was at Wolverine from approximately February to
June of this year. He described the placement as horrible and
stated that the staff would threaten him and other kids would
instigate him. When asked for specific examples, he indicated he
could not remember. He did report recalling that Staff 1 stated
she would “lay him out”. He described that as meaning she would
knock him to the ground. He could not remember specific
instances of being instigated by other youth but said they would
try and make him mad on purpose. Youth A was specifically asked
if he recalled Youth B from Wolverine Center and he responded
yes. He further stated that Youth B was "sexually harassing" him.
He confirmed Youth B was a youth and not staff. He described
him as tall, black and having an afro hairstyle. He described
sexually harassing as Youth B making comments to him, but
stated he could not remember what was specifically said to him.
He denied Youth B ever physically touched him. He reported he
told Supervisor 1 about Youth B harassing him, but the staff did
not do anything. He stated that staff kept them separate from
each other after he told them about Youth B harassing him. He
denied having any additional information to share.
On 08/22/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Youth
B. DHHS specialist was present in person. Youth B reported that
he remembered Youth A from Wolverine Center. He asked if he
was being interviewed because staff was mean to Youth A. He
gave examples that staff would call Youth A an “autistic bitch”. He
also reported that staff would antagonize Youth A and his
imaginary friend. Staff would point to an empty space and say
that the imaginary friend wanted to fight, and Youth A would run
over and start punching the air. Youth B could not specifically
recall which staff would do this. Youth B reported that he did not
get along well with Youth A. He recalled it being two instances
that Youth A tried to fight him. Youth B denied ever making any
sort of sexual comments toward Youth A and was very upset
about the allegations against him. Attempts to redirect him and
reassure him that these were just allegations was unsuccessful.
On 08/28/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 1
via telephone by DHHS Specialist. DCWL consultant obtained
this information via review of social work contact of DHHS
specialist. Staff 1 remembered both Youth A and Youth B. She
3

recalled one instance where they got into an argument because
Youth A kept using the word “nigger” and it made Youth B upset.
She stated she encouraged Youth B to ignore it because of the
mental health issues with Youth A and his limitation to
understanding what he was saying was bad. Staff 1 denied Youth
A ever said anything to her about being sexually harassed and
she did not hear anything about it. She said Youth B had a
reputation for fighting and most youth did not want to be around
him. She was asked if she ever heard staff call any of the youths
names and she admitted that both staff and supervisors there call
youth names and say derogatory things but she would not say
which staff in particular. She recalled Lead Supervisor called a
youth stupid and retarded and stated that his “momma should
have swallowed him”. She further stated that Wolverine attempts
to cover things up and the youth are always going AWOL because
they have no voice and no one is advocating for them.
On 08/28/2024 the following interviews were completed by
DHHS specialist at Wolverine Human Services unless
otherwise noted. DCWL consultant obtained information
from review of social work contacts.
Youth C was interviewed and recalled both Youth A and Youth B
when they were placed at the facility. He denied recalling any
fights or disagreements between the two youth. He denied
hearing staff call youth negative names and described a positive
experience with Supervisor 1 and Staff 1.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed and denied knowledge of any fights
between Youth A and Youth B. He further denied that Youth A
ever made any accusations against Youth B, specifically nothing
that could be sexual harassment. Supervisor 1 recalled that
Youth A had a habit of talking to himself but does not remember
anything about an imaginary friend. He denied hearing staff call
Youth A or any other youth names and stated that would result in
a write up.
Lead Supervisor was interviewed and recalled both Youth A and
Youth B being placed at the agency. She did not recall a lot about
Youth A but stated Youth B had lots of issues with other youth.
She recalled that the agency tried to keep them separated, not
due to anything sexually inappropriate, but because Youth A was
easily triggered by Youth B. She denied recalling Youth A
reporting any sort of sexual harassment and denied hearing staff
call youth inappropriate names. Lead supervisor specifically
denied telling a youth "your mother should have swallowed you".
4

She attributed the allegations to staff being upset with her due to
her role in issuing discipline and terminations.
On 09/05/2024 a DHHS Closing Conference was held. DHHS
Specialist, Area Manager and Foster Care Worker were present.
No findings of abuse or neglect were noted.
On 09/10/2024 a telephone call was made to Therapist by DHHS
specialist. This information was obtained by review of the social
work contacts of DHHS Specialist. He denied that Youth A had
ever made any disclosures regarding Youth B sexually harassing
him, nor any disclosures regarding staff calling him names.
On 09/19/2024 the following interviews were completed at
Wolverine Human Services unless otherwise noted.
Youth D and Youth E were interviewed, and both denied
knowledge of possible sexual harassment of Youth A by Youth B.
They also denied that staff call youth names.
Lead Supervisor and Staff 2 were also interviewed. Both denied
that they have ever called youth negative names or have heard
other staff engage in that type of behavior. They both also denied
knowledge of any type of sexual harassment of Youth A by Youth
B or any other youth.
On 10/08/2024 a telephone interview was completed with
Supervisor 1. He denied knowledge of Lead Supervisor or Staff
1 making derogatory comments or threats to any youth at the
facility. He further denied that any youth had made reports to him
regarding name calling or threats being made to them by any
Wolverine staff.
On 10/08/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 1.
She denied ever making threats or negative comments toward
Youth A.
On 10/17/2024 the following interviews were completed at
Wolverine Human Services unless otherwise noted.
Staff 3 was interviewed and denied knowledge of staff making
threats or name calling toward any youth at the facility.
Youth G and Youth F were interviewed, and both denied
experiencing staff calling them names or making threats toward
5

them. They further denied knowledge of this happening to other
youth at the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Reports involving Youth A: Incident reports involving
Youth A were reviewed. There were a total of 15 IR’s provided for
review. The incidents detail property damage, threats against
staff, and attempted self-injury. There were no reports that
documented or referenced any inappropriate sexual behavior or
involvement of Youth B. The only mention of another resident
within the IR’s involved Youth A punching an unnamed youth.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Management Policy:
All staff are to be certified in Crisis Prevention Institute Non-
Violent Crisis Intervention. Non-violent physical restrictions are
only to be used to protect clients or others from unanticipated or
severely aggressive behavior that places them at risk of violence
or injury if no intervention occurs. Interventions must be guided by
a number of factors, including safety of other clients and staff, size
and strength of client, degree of past violent behavior, whether the
client has a weapon, physical or health conditions of the client,
client's Individual Crisis Management Plan. Post-incident
debriefing must also occur.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency is found to be in
compliance with licensing rule 4126.1. There is no evidence to
support that agency staff failed to provide proper supervision to
prevent inappropriate sexual contact between two youth. In
addition, there was no evidence to support staff using
inappropriate language toward youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Section requirements; staff qualifications. (4) A person with ongoing

of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
6

Allegation Agency staff arrive to work under the influence of alcohol.
Investigation Interviews:
On 08/22/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Youth
B. DHHS specialist was present in person. He reported that
Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 were "not good staff" and that they would
go out and drink together then come to work drunk.
On 10/03/2024 an in-person meeting was held with the Chief
Administrator. She denied knowledge of any staff arriving to
work under the influence of alcohol. She also denied ever
receiving such compliant from any resident or other staff.
On 10/08/2024 a telephone interview was completed with
Supervisor 1. He denied that he has ever come to work under
the influence of alcohol. He further denied knowledge of any staff
coming to work under the influence of alcohol or any other drugs.
On 10/08/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 1.
She denied ever arriving to work under the influence of drugs or
alcohol and denied knowledge of any other staff doing so either.
On 10/17/2024 the following interviews were completed at
Wolverine Human Services unless otherwise noted.
Staff 3 was interviewed and denied she has ever reported to work
under the influence and denied knowledge of any other staff
reporting to work under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
Youth G and Youth F were interviewed, and both denied
knowledge of any staff reporting to work under the influence of
drugs or alcohol. Youth F indicated that he has thought he
smelled marijuana in the building before, but did not have
knowledge of any specific staff that has been under the influence
or seemed to be under the influence of any drugs.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was no evidence to
support allegations that staff show up to work under the influence.
Both staff and youth were interviewed, and all denied knowledge
of any staff arriving to work under the influence of alcohol.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

Rule Code
Grievance procedures
Title
Rule Code &
CCI Rule 400.4132: (1) An agency shall have and follow a written
Section
grievance handling procedure for youth and their families.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are not allowed to file grievances.
Investigation Interviews:
On 08/28/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 1
via telephone by DHHS Specialist. DCWL consultant obtained
this information via review of social work contact of DHHS
specialist. Staff 1 reported youth at Wolverine have filed
grievances, but she does not think anything gets done because
she has not seen any investigations.
On 08/28/2024 the following interviews were completed by
DHHS specialist at Wolverine Human Services unless
otherwise noted. DCWL consultant obtained information
from review of social work contacts.
Chief Administrator was interviewed and advised that she did
not recall Youth A or Youth B submitting a grievance form. She
reported the agency has lock boxes for youth to submit grievances
and the forms are given directly to quality assurance manager for
resolution. She provided copies of the policy for review.
Youth C was interviewed and stated he was aware of the process
for a grievance but denied ever having to file one.
On 09/19/2024 the following interviews were completed at
Wolverine Human Services unless otherwise noted.
Youth D and Youth E were interviewed, both youth denied having
to filed a grievance since being placed at the facility. They
confirmed they are aware of the process to do so, if needed.
Lead Supervisor and Staff 2 were also interviewed, both
reported that youth are advised of the grievance policy and that
grievances are addressed as they come in.
On 10/03/2024 an in-person meeting was held with the Chief
Administrator. She denied knowledge of any complaints by
youth of inability to file grievances. She further confirmed that all
8

youth are advised of ability and process to file a grievance during
the intake process.
On 10/08/2024 a interview was completed with Supervisor 1 via
telephone. He denied ever being advised by any youth or other
staff of concerns of youth being able to file a grievance. He
further advised that all youth are advised of their ability and the
process of filing a grievance.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Grievance Policy:
Wolverine maintains a formal mechanism through which clients
and families can express/resolve grievances, which includes the
right to file a grievance without interference or retaliation, timely
notification of resolution, at least one level of review that does not
involve the person about whom the complaint has been made or
the person who reached the decision under review, and the right
of the client or a family member to be heard by a person
delegated to review responsibility. A form should be available for
all clients and completed forms should be placed in a locked box,
which should be checked daily. Forms should be forwarded to the
assigned Recipient Rights Advocate. The Advocate should meet
with the client within 7 days to discuss whether an investigation
will be opened and/or if there have been any findings. Grievances
will be detailed in month end reports and reviewed for trends
quarterly.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was not sufficient
evidence to support the allegation of youth not being able to file a
grievance. Both youth and staff were interviewed and denied that
youth are not allowed to file grievances. Staff and youth reported
that youth have the ability and are aware of the process to file a
grievance.
Technical Assistance: Based on the report of Youth B, the
agency, was however provided with TA. It was suggested that a
review occur with all staff and youth to ensure clarity regarding the
grievance policy and procedure to file a grievance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
9

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
